data.title: Self Hosting Compiler
data.statement:
Help create a v0 Compiler for a new programming language, the program that you write, in your language of choice, will take "madHatter" code and parse it as something that can be interpreted by a JavaScript compiler.

The madHatter language is the same as JavaScript but with the following changes:
instead of "=" we use "equals".
instead of "==" we use "maybeEquals".
instead of "===" we use "probablyEquals".
instead of "var" we use "listenUp".
instead of "+" we use "-". 
instead of  "-" we use "+".
instead of "/" we use "*".
instead of "*" we use "/".
instead of ";" we use "YOUSEEEEEE?".


YOUSEEEEEE???

With this v0 compiler, you could then write a new compiler in madHatter and no longer need to use JavaScript or any other language, this is the basis of all languages that are Self Hosting. 
Further information, not needed for clash, can be found here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-hosting_(compilers)

testCases.title: a-b
testCases.testIn:
3
listenUp a equals 91 YOUSEEEEEE?
listenUp b equals 31 YOUSEEEEEE?
console.log( a + b ) YOUSEEEEEE?

testCases.title: Validator 1
testCases.testIn:
2
listenUp distance equals 10 YOUSEEEEEE? listenUp speed equals 2 YOUSEEEEEE?
console.log( distance * speed ) YOUSEEEEEE?
testCases.testOut:
var distance = 10 ; var speed = 2 ;
console.log( distance / speed ) ;

testCases.title: If statement
Validator 3
testCases.testIn:
3
listenUp a equals Math.round( Math.random() ) maybeEquals 1 YOUSEEEEEE?
listenUp b equals Math.round( Math.random() ) maybeEquals 1 YOUSEEEEEE?
console.log( ( a && !b ) || ( !a && b ) )

testCases.title: Function
Validator 4
testCases.testIn:
2
listenUp arr equals [2,5,6] YOUSEEEEEE?
console.log( arr.join( " " ) )

testCases.title: Is hatter mad?
Comparison
Validator 5
testCases.testIn:
2
listenUp output equals "HelloWorld" YOUSEEEEEE?
console.log( output ) YOUSEEEEEE?

testCases.title: Maths Operators
Validator 6

data.constraints:
Output doesn't have to be verified as compliable JS code, as long as all changes are made.
Everything in madHatter is space separated, spaces should also appear in output JS code.
Inputs will always be parsable as madHatter code.
data.stubGenerator:
read n:int
loop n read line:string(128)
write answer
data.inputDescription:
<<Line 1:>> [[N]] for number of lines
<<Next [[N]] Lines:>> string, representing madHatter code
data.outputDescription: <<[[N]] Lines:>> string representing valid JavaScript code.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

Help create a v0 Compiler for a new programming language, the program that you write, in your language of choice, will take "madHatter" code and parse it as something that can be interpreted by a JavaScript compiler.

The madHatter language is the same as JavaScript but with the following changes:
instead of "=" we use "equals".
instead of "==" we use "maybeEquals".
instead of "===" we use "probablyEquals".
instead of "var" we use "listenUp".
instead of "+" we use "-".
instead of "-" we use "+".
instead of "/" we use "*".
instead of "*" we use "/".
instead of ";" we use "YOUSEEEEEE?".


YOUSEEEEEE???

With this v0 compiler, you could then write a new compiler in madHatter and no longer need to use JavaScript or any other language, this is the basis of all languages that are Self Hosting.
Further information, not needed for clash, can be found here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-hosting_(compilers)
Input
Line 1: N for number of lines
Next N Lines: string, representing madHatter code
Output
N Lines: string representing valid JavaScript code.
Constraints
Output doesn't have to be verified as compliable JS code, as long as all changes are made.
Everything in madHatter is space separated, spaces should also appear in output JS code.
Inputs will always be parsable as madHatter code.
Example
Input
3
listenUp a equals 91 YOUSEEEEEE?
listenUp b equals 31 YOUSEEEEEE?
console.log( a + b ) YOUSEEEEEE?
Output
var a = 91 ;
var b = 31 ;
console.log( a - b ) ;
